thread.title: Website spins city's whims | savannahnow.com

author: DispatchDaemon
title: Website spins city's whims | savannahnow.com
text:
The City of Savannah has launched a page on its website that officials say is meant to answer questions the public may have about decisions the city has made or services it offers.
Unveiled this week, a month before municipal elections, the website, labeled Just the FAQs, is free of “spin,” according to city spokesman Bret Bell.
The site is informative, given the issues facing City Council incumbents and the mayor, who are all facing challengers in November. However, the information isn’t necessarily accurate.
Open a link to a page on the long-awaited Cultural Arts Center, and the first sentence is less than truthful: “The City has the funding in place, and has recently completed the design phase of a plan to build a new center for the arts in Savannah.”
The city has a plan for funding, but the money is not in place. Most of the funding will come from Special Purpose Local Option Sales Tax funding that was initially approved by voters in 2006. At that time, the budget for the center was $13.4 million.
Since then, the property at Hall Street and Martin Luther King Jr. Boulevard that was originally purchased for the center, at a cost of $1 million in 2007, was deemed too small, and the city has moved the site for the center to city-owned land at the corner Oglethorpe Avenue and Montgomery Street.
Meanwhile, the budget for the arts center has ballooned to nearly $25 million. A design is still waiting for approval, and the center isn’t expected to be completed until 2017 at the earliest. The result will be a building that took 17 years to complete at a budget double of what was originally proposed and will be insufficient according to two experts who should know: the Savannah Music Festival’s Rob Gibson and the Telfair Museums’ Lisa Grove.
As a result of all this rigmarole, the city came up with a financial plan to bridge the gap between proposed cost and available funding. It’s a plan that makes some whimsical assumptions. One assumption is that the city will sell the Hall Street site for the $1 million it paid for the property. It’s been on the market since 2009.
The second assumption is that the city will collect another $500,000 from the sale of a piece of property on the project site along Martin Luther King Jr. Boulevard.
But perhaps the most fanciful part of the plan relies on each alderman forgoing $100,000 out of $1.5 million each was to receive from current SPLOST dollars for district neighborhood projects, a proposal the alderman have not signed off on nor appear in any hurry to do so, especially in an election year.
And regarding the “completed” design phase, the Historic Review Board has approved the mass and height of the center. The actual design elements still have to go before the council.
We support and appreciate the city’s effort to address citizens’ questions and concerns on the city website — and we await the date that residents can conveniently pay their water bills online, and give these payments the same priority as paying parking tickets and red-light violation fines — but the timing is troubling and the accuracy leaves much to be desired. And based on the cultural arts center page, it’s not “spin” free. Instead, it’s enough to make one dizzy.
